instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2179: What is A2179? A2179 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2020 with EMC 3302, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01958..
definitions.820-01958: What is 820-01958? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.CPU_VR_EN: What is CPU_VR_EN? CPU_VR_EN is an enable signal for CPU VCORE that is present when it is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. ALL_SYS_PWRGD, PM_RSMRST_L, PM_SLP_SUS_L, and PM_SLP_S3_L are necessary prerequisites for CPU_VR_EN to be present. .
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> dead only Fan Spin from time to time
threads.message:
As always for T2 machines, start with DFU mode.
More information available here:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]
Be sure to follow all the steps in the linked DFU tutorial.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> dead only Fan Spin from time to time
threads.message:
Tried to boot in DFU mode and tried to Restore as well as Repair - only got an Error saying that the Device was either disconected or connected twice.

Edit: Now tried Recovery Mode - Error 4010 but the Error Text is the same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> dead only Fan Spin from time to time
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is stable?
Check it in both cases, when fan spins and not.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> dead only Fan Spin from time to time
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is stable at 12.89V Fan did not spin since DFU and Recovery mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> dead only Fan Spin from time to time
threads.message: You should check if doesn't drop at the time you get the error.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> dead only Fan Spin from time to time
threads.message:
It "drops" to 12.69V shortly before the Error appears.

But I don't think this has to be the Error right ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> dead only Fan Spin from time to time
threads.message:
That could be the sign of T2 communication problem.
May be T2 internal issue, or something else blocks it.
Check if any AWAKE, or SLPS2R voltage drops at same moment too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> dead only Fan Spin from time to time
threads.message: All of the SLPS2R Voltages drop 1 sec. before it fails. I also observed that the Recovery Mode is only Possible if battery is connected. Is this normal?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> dead only Fan Spin from time to time
threads.message:
The voltage drop explains the DFU error.
Do you note dropping voltage with battery connected too?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> dead only Fan Spin from time to time
threads.message: Yes it only starts in DFU or Recovery with Battery connected. If Battery disconnected, the Board only shows this LED lit up but not in Recovery or DFU mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> dead only Fan Spin from time to time
threads.message: Without battery, only charger, what voltages can you find on the board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> dead only Fan Spin from time to time
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.58V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> = 12.58V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>  = 5.10V
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P5VG3S</SIGNAL>  = 12.57V
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.57V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>  = 3.29V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>  = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL>  = 1.804V
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>CPU_VR_EN</SIGNAL> = 0.189V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_PCH_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0,00V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> dead only Fan Spin from time to time
threads.message:
Machine starts in Recovery Mode and stays on for long time?
Read the DFU tuorial linked on the forum and try to follow all its steps exactly.
Other people complained about autostart in Recovery Mode, but they finally succeed to put it in DFU.

AWAKE voltages drop even with battery and charger, both connected?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> dead only Fan Spin from time to time
threads.message: Yes both connected, then they drop and Come back again after a half a second

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> dead only Fan Spin from time to time
threads.message:
Any fault history available?
Check for liquid sign; especially on the audio board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> dead only Fan Spin from time to time
threads.message:
I finally got into DFU Mode now. No Fault History available and no Liquid Damage sign..

EDIT: I tried to Revive the Device via:  [B]Actions > Advanced > Revive Device[/B] but it shows Error 75 "Missing Data Volume"
If i try to "Recover" it in DFU Mode it brings up the old Error with: "the Device was either disconected or connected twice." Device added from invalid state Restoring.. I have no clue why this Error shows up..

Can you access it in Target Disk mode?
